sense.name: official offer to purchase something at a specified price
sense.examples: Their tender to buy the company at ten dollars a share was rejected. They have questioned the legality of blocking tenders by foreign companies for U.S. firms.

sense.name: an official medium of exchange, currency
sense.examples: This old currency is no longer considered to be legal tender. Pennies are a nuisance, but they are still legal tender. At this resort they give you strings of beads as tender for all your purchases.

sense.name: a small boat that transports people and goods between ship and shore
sense.examples: The tender took us out to the mooring where Bob's 40-foot sloop was. You need to call the tender with the air horn when you want to come ashore. John's son earned college money one summer by driving a tender around Boston Harbor.

sense.name: a ship that supplies other ships with goods and personnel
sense.examples: Two tenders were destroyed by enemy torpedoes so supplies to our ships will be delayed. The military is transporting food and ammunition to the western fleet via tenders.

sense.name: an overseer or caregiver to someone or something
sense.examples: His brother is a tender of the elderly at a nursing home. She is a volunteer tender of the botanical gardens.

sense.name: train car attached to locomotive to supply it with fuel and water
sense.examples: Additional fuel for the locomotive is carried in its tender.

sense.name: a strip of cooked chicken breast, often breaded
sense.examples: Mary ordered chicken tenders for the children. That fast food place offers chicken tenders with three dipping sauces.
